15.25.text:
- (Voiceover) Please welcome
our host for today's contest,

17.28.text:
Arts Education Director of the
Mississippi Arts Commission,

28.26.text:
- Charlotte Smelser: On
behalf of the Mississippi Arts

30.33.text:
Commission and our partners,
the National Endowment

32.33.text:
for the Arts and the
Poetry Foundation,

35.04.text:
I welcome you to the
11th annual Poetry Out Loud

41.88.text:
This year more than 370,000
students in nearly 2400

47.85.text:
schools participated
in Poetry Out Loud,

51.49.text:
a poetry education program
that is offered free-of-charge

54.89.text:
to high school students and
teachers across our nation.

59.09.text:
The highlight of the program
is the National Recitation

61.83.text:
Contest in which 53
contestants - one from each of

65.77.text:
the 50 states, Puerto
Rico, the US Virgin Islands,

72.04.text:
- recite for up to $20,000
in prize money.

77.51.text:
Thirty-eight high schools
from across our state - from

80.58.text:
Meridian to Vicksburg, and
from Southaven to Biloxi --

83.68.text:
began the journey toward
today's contest when they

86.69.text:
registered to participate in
Mississippi's Poetry Out Loud

89.82.text:
program at the beginning
of the academic year.

93.26.text:
In some schools this began
in the English classroom,

97.00.text:
in others in the theatre
classroom and still others,

100.13.text:
with an interested
teacher or club advisor.

103.74.text:
This lead to an in-school
Poetry Out Loud contest

106.74.text:
that was held just before
the winter holidays.

115.28.text:
in Mississippi's Poetry
Out Loud this year.

119.39.text:
In February, the school
champions represented their

121.69.text:
schools at one of three
Regional Contests held across

124.56.text:
the state and, from those
three Regional contests,

133.00.text:
There will be three
rounds in today's contest.

135.34.text:
Each contestant has prepared
three poems and each will

137.77.text:
recite one in Round One
and another in Round Two.

141.84.text:
The three top-scoring
contestants will then each

144.38.text:
recite their third poem to
determine who will represent

148.08.text:
Mississippi at the
National Recitation Contest

154.65.text:
With my personal best
wishes to all the contestants,

157.72.text:
it is my pleasure now
to introduce

159.66.text:
our Master of Ceremonies
for this Contest.

162.26.text:
Kevin Farrell is the
Assistant Director of Radio

171.44.text:
graduating with a
Bachelor of Arts degree

173.81.text:
in Radio, Television and Film
Production in 1984.

179.11.text:
During his 31 years with
Mississippi Public Broadcasting,

182.98.text:
Farrell has served as
a reporter, producer

188.39.text:
Currently, he is the
host for a number

190.49.text:
of local informational
shows that air

195.50.text:
Please welcome Mississippi
Public Broadcasting's own

210.14.text:
and thanks also to our
guest musicians from

211.41.text:
the "Pine Belt Pickers", Kyle
Baughman and Ben Steadman.

220.89.text:
First let me tell you how proud
Mississippi Public Broadcasting

227.59.text:
We believe that academic
contests should and do stand

230.56.text:
on the same stage as all
other pursuits of excellence,

235.60.text:
not only our attention,
but our respect.

238.84.text:
Poetry Out Loud seeks to
promote the art of poetry

241.81.text:
in both the classroom
and the community.

244.01.text:
The program provides an entry
point for many students

246.65.text:
to learn to love
poetry and, for many,

248.95.text:
to introduce them
to poems that will

250.95.text:
stay with them
for a lifetime.

253.79.text:
Poetry Out Loud judges evaluate
each recitation independently

257.62.text:
using a predefined
six-level scoring system.

261.06.text:
In addition, an accuracy judge
follows the text

263.80.text:
to monitor accuracy and
a prompter is available

269.67.text:
Judging recitations is one of
the most important -

272.57.text:
and most difficult -
aspects of Poetry Out Loud.

275.81.text:
Judges are asked to evaluate
very different recitations,

278.88.text:
each displaying an impressive
level of excellence,

281.65.text:
and they must decide
how well students represent

283.55.text:
complex poems that
may lend themselves

287.92.text:
The integrity of Poetry Out
Loud rests on the work

290.26.text:
of the judges at each and
every level of the contest.

294.39.text:
Serving on today's panel
of judges are:

296.93.text:
Poet and short-story writer,
and instructor of English

299.83.text:
at Jackson State University,
C. Leigh McInnis.

308.84.text:
Author, Mississippi Arts
Commission Roster Artist

311.21.text:
and Teaching Artist, and
Mississippi Humanities
Speaker, Richelle Putnam.

319.85.text:
Assistant Professor in the
School of Journalism

322.36.text:
and Media Studies at Jackson
State University,

330.43.text:
Artistic Director of
Jackson's New Stage Theatre,

338.14.text:
Poet, writer and Mississippi
Arts Commission Roster Artist,

346.18.text:
And courtesy of the
Mississippi Arts Commission,

349.85.text:
our Accuracy Judge is
Connie Souto Learman,

353.09.text:
our prompter is Diane Williams
and tabulating the scores

357.16.text:
are Shirley Smith
and Emily Tschiffely.

363.46.text:
Poetry Out Loud recitations
are scored in five categories:

376.78.text:
It is interesting to
note that Poetry Out Loud

379.11.text:
is not a competition -
it is a contest:

382.05.text:
If it were a competition,
the contestants would all be

384.62.text:
reciting the same poems and
the judges would be choosing

390.02.text:
In Poetry Out Loud, the judges
evaluate each recitation

393.06.text:
independently according to
the five scoring categories

396.80.text:
using a predefined
six-level scoring system.

399.93.text:
In other words, the judges
do not select the finalists,

405.44.text:
And now we begin Round One
of the Poetry Out Loud 2016

419.99.text:
- "The Obligation to Be
Happy" by Linda Pastan.

427.19.text:
It is more onerous than the
rites of beauty or housework,

434.90.text:
But you expect it
of me casually,

438.04.text:
the way you expect
the sun to come up,

441.64.text:
not in spite of rain or
clouds but because of them.

446.81.text:
And so I smile, as if my own
fidelity to sadness were

450.82.text:
a hidden vice- that
downward tug on my mouth,

455.59.text:
my old suspicion that
health and love are brief

460.19.text:
irrelevancies, no more than
laughter in the warm dark

468.30.text:
I try to hoist it on my
narrow shoulders again-

472.04.text:
a knapsack heavy
with gold coins.

475.61.text:
I stumble around the
house, bump into things.

507.37.text:
Heartbeat trembling your
kingdom of leaves near

512.51.text:
the ceremony of water, I
never insisted on you.

523.89.text: I was the Empress of Delay.

527.29.text: But it can't be put off now.

530.30.text:
On the sacred branch of
my only voice - I insist.

536.67.text:
Insist for us all, which
is the job of the voice,

546.85.text:
Else what am I for, what
use am I if I don't insist?

598.13.text:
A man came home
and chucked

600.43.text:
his girlfriend's cat In
the wood chipper.

611.08.text:
A lot Of other
little things went wrong.

613.85.text:
He spat On her father,
who came out

617.88.text:
He also broke her
pinky, Stole her checks,

625.76.text:
But she stood by him,
stood strong,

629.63.text:
through it all,
Because she loved him.

636.47.text:
She actually said that, and
then she went And married him.

647.58.text:
Don't try to understand what
another Person means by love.

673.31.text:
What the scale tells you is
how much the earth has missed

678.14.text:
you, body, how it wants you
back again after you leave it

683.12.text: to go forth into the light.

686.62.text:
Do you remember how earth
hardly noticed you then?

691.49.text:
Others would rock
you in their arms,

694.36.text:
warm in the flow that fed
you, coaxed you upright.

699.40.text:
Then earth began to claim
you with spots and fevers,

705.81.text:
began to lick at you
with a bruised knee,

709.24.text:
a bloody shin, and
finally to stoke you,

713.98.text:
body, drumming intimate coded
messages through music you

720.05.text:
danced to unawares, there in
your dreaming and your poems

729.70.text:
Body, how useful you
became, how lucky,

735.44.text:
heavy with news
and breakage, rich,

740.37.text:
and sad, sometimes, imagining
that greedy zero you must have

745.91.text:
been, that promising
empty sack of possibilities,

754.82.text:
But look at you now, body,
soft old shoe that love wears

759.33.text:
when it's stirring, look down,
look how earth wants

767.13.text:
what you weigh,
needs what you know.

795.06.text:
Don't take it
personal, they said;

799.20.text:
but I did, I took it all quite
personal- the breeze

805.37.text:
and the river and the
color of the fields;

809.68.text:
the price of
grapefruit and stamps,

813.58.text:
the wet hair of women
in the rain-

816.72.text:
And I cursed
what hurt me

820.22.text:
and I praised
what gave me joy,

823.49.text:
the most simple-minded
of possible responses.

828.39.text:
The government
reminded me of my father,

832.57.text:
with its
deafness and its laws,

836.64.text:
and the weather
reminded me of my mom,

845.08.text:
Enjoy it while you can,
they said of Happiness

851.25.text:
Think first,
they said of Talk

855.66.text:
Get over it, they said
at the School of Broken Hearts

863.70.text:
but I couldn't
and I didn't

867.40.text:
and I don't believe
in the clean break;

871.14.text:
I believe in the
compound fracture

874.31.text:
served with a
sauce of dirty regret,

878.24.text:
I believe in saying it all
and taking it all back

886.29.text:
while the air fills up
with I'm-Sorries

889.26.text:
like wheeling birds and the
trees look seasick in the wind.

898.33.text:
Can you blame me
for making a scene?

908.17.text:
the moon disappearing
over a ridge of cloud.

914.11.text:
I was the dog, chained
in some fool's backyard;

919.42.text:
barking and barking: trying
to convince everything else

940.64.text:
- "There Are Birds Here"
by Jamaal May.

954.19.text:
so many birds here
is what

959.73.text:
when they said those
birds were metaphors

962.83.text:
for what is trapped between
buildings and buildings.

971.04.text:
The birds are here to root
around for bread the girl's

974.04.text:
hands tear and
toss like confetti.

979.31.text:
No, I don't mean the
bread is torn like cotton,

983.75.text:
I said confetti, and no
not the confetti a tank

991.56.text:
I mean the confetti a boy
can't stop smiling about and

997.60.text:
no his smile isn't much
like a skeleton at all.

1002.03.text:
And no his neighborhood
is not like a war zone.

1008.47.text:
I am trying to say his
neighborhood is as tattered

1018.28.text:
as shadow pierced by sun and
light parted by shadow-dance

1029.13.text:
but they won't stop
saying how lovely the ruins,

1037.44.text:
how ruined the
lovely children must be

1059.56.text:
- "Fishing on the Susquehanna
in July" by Billy Collins.

1069.04.text:
I have never been fishing
on the Susquehanna or on

1073.37.text:
any other river for that matter
to be perfectly honest.

1078.34.text:
Not in July or any month
have I had the pleasure-

1082.65.text:
if it is a pleasure- of fishing
on the Susquehanna.

1088.12.text:
I am more likely to be found
in a quiet room like this one-

1094.19.text:
a painting of a
woman on the wall,

1097.56.text:
a bowl of tangerines on the
table- trying to manufacture

1102.27.text:
the sensation of
fishing on the Susquehanna.

1106.31.text:
There is little doubt that
others have been fishing on

1109.41.text:
the Susquehanna, rowing
upstream in a wooden boat,

1115.31.text:
sliding the oars under the
water then raising them

1121.29.text:
But the nearest I have
ever come to fishing on the

1123.12.text:
Susquehanna was one afternoon
in a museum in Philadelphia

1127.79.text:
when I balanced a little egg
of time in front of a painting

1134.27.text:
in which that river curled
around a bend under a blue

1138.80.text:
cloud-ruffled sky, dense
trees along the banks,

1145.34.text:
and a fellow with a red
bandanna sitting in a small,

1148.41.text:
green flat-bottom boat holding
the thin whip of a pole.

1154.75.text:
That is something I am
unlikely ever to do,

1159.29.text:
I remember saying to myself
and the person next to me.

1165.36.text:
Then I blinked and moved on
to other American scenes

1170.60.text:
of haystacks, water
whitening over rocks,

1175.24.text:
even one of a brown hare who
seemed so wired with alertness

1180.31.text:
I imagined him springing
right out of the frame.

1200.43.text:
- "The Art Room" by Shara
McCallum, for my sisters.

1209.38.text:
Because we did not have
threads of turquoise,

1213.48.text:
silver, and gold, we
could not sew a sun nor sky.

1220.95.text:
And our hands
became balls of fire.

1224.39.text:
And our arms spread
open like wings.

1229.80.text:
Because we had no
chalk or pastels,

1235.20.text:
no toad, forest, or
morning-grass slats of paper,

1241.54.text:
we had no color
for creatures.

1245.41.text:
So we squatted and
sprang, squatted and sprang.

1250.65.text:
Four young girls,
plaits heavy on our backs,

1256.39.text:
our feet were beating drums,
drawing rhythms from the floor;

1264.90.text:
our tongues touched
teeth and were reeds.

1291.16.text:
You saved me, you
should remember me.

1295.76.text:
The spring of the year;
young men buying tickets

1301.77.text:
Laughter, because the air
is full of apple blossoms.

1309.38.text:
When I woke up, I
realized I was capable

1315.88.text:
I remember sounds like
that from my childhood,

1318.95.text:
laughter for no cause,
simply because

1322.56.text:
the world is beautiful,
something like that.

1332.93.text:
Deckhands raising and
lowering the colored flags.

1337.34.text:
And by the lake's edge, a
young man throws his hat into

1341.57.text:
the water; perhaps his
sweetheart has accepted him.

1348.31.text:
Crucial sounds or gestures
like a track laid down before

1353.35.text:
the larger themes
and then unused, buried.

1363.80.text:
My mother holding out a
plate of little cakes-

1369.20.text:
as far as I remember,
changed in no detail,

1375.61.text:
the moment vivid, intact, having
never been exposed to light,

1382.55.text:
so that I woke elated,
at my age hungry for life,

1391.22.text:
By the tables,
patches of new grass,

1396.66.text:
the pale green pieced
into the dark existing ground.

1403.30.text:
Surely spring has
been returned to me,

1407.24.text:
this time not as a lover
but a messenger of death,

1414.25.text:
yet it is still spring, it
is still meant tenderly.

1431.20.text:
- Kevin Farrell: This
concludes Round One of the

1432.83.text:
Poetry Out Loud 2016
Mississippi Recitation Contest.

1436.04.text:
We'll now proceed
directly to Round Two,

1437.97.text:
during which we'll hear
a second recitation

1455.32.text:
The jaunty crop-haired graying
Women in grocery stores,

1459.43.text:
Their clothes boyish and neat,
New mittens or clean sneakers,

1464.46.text:
Clean hands,
hips not bad still,

1471.20.text:
Fresh melons and soap-or the
big Balding young men in work

1476.08.text:
shoes And green work pants,
beer belly And white T-shirt,

1481.31.text:
the porky walk
Back to the truck,

1483.28.text:
polite; possible To
feel briefly like Jesus,

1487.82.text:
A gust of diffuse tenderness
Crossing the dark spaces

1492.59.text:
To where the dry self
burrows Or nests,

1496.13.text:
something that stirs,
Watching the kinds of people

1499.63.text: On the street for a while-

1502.27.text:
But how love falters
and flags

1504.90.text:
When anyone's difficult
eyes come Into focus,

1509.11.text:
terrible gaze of
a unique Soul,

1516.08.text:
my friend In his divorced
schoolteacher Apartment,

1519.39.text:
his own unsuspected
Paintings hung everywhere,

1523.02.text:
Which his wife kept
in a closet-

1525.39.text:
Not, he says, that she
wasn't Perfectly right;

1529.36.text:
or me, mis-hearing My rock
radio sing my self-pity:

1535.00.text:
"The Angels Wished Him
Dead"-all The hideous,

1539.37.text:
sudden stare of self, Soul
showing through like the

1542.88.text:
lizard Ancestry showing
in the frontal gaze

1546.51.text:
Of a robin busy
on the lawn.

1549.65.text:
In the movies, when the
sensitive Young Jewish soldier

1554.69.text:
nearly drowns Trying
to rescue the thrashing

1560.29.text:
swimming across The
river raked by Nazi fire,

1564.26.text:
The awful part is the part
truth: Hate my whole kind,

1570.14.text:
but me, Love me
for myself.

1574.27.text:
The weather Changes
in the black of night,

1577.14.text:
And the dream-wind, bowling
across The sopping open spaces

1581.41.text:
Of roads, golf courses,
parking lots,

1584.88.text:
Flails a commotion In
the dripping treetops,

1588.92.text:
Tries a half-rotten shingle
Or a down-hung branch,

1593.16.text:
and we All dream it,
the dark wind crossing

1612.11.text:
- "Give All to Love"
by Ralph Waldo Emerson.

1670.37.text:
And the outlets
of the sky.

1673.01.text:
It was never for
the mean;

1700.87.text:
One word more
thy heart behoved,

1704.24.text:
One pulse more
of firm endeavor,

1720.55.text:
Cling with life
to the maid;

1733.23.text:
Of a joy apart
from thee,

1741.01.text:
Nor thou detain
her vesture's hem,

1743.78.text:
Nor the palest rose
she flung

1750.45.text:
Though thou loved
her as thyself,

1753.15.text:
As a self of
purer clay,

1756.69.text:
Though her parting
dims the day,

1793.59.text:
A little girl made of sugar
and spice and everything nice

1798.56.text:
was eaten by someone
with a sweet tooth

1801.43.text:
the size of an
elephant's tusk.

1804.97.text:
Ah, he said, this darn
tooth, it's driving me nuts.

1816.21.text:
It's the little girl's
father who says,

1819.42.text:
have you seen a little girl
made of sugar and spice

1829.76.text:
what's that thing sticking
out of your mouth

1836.03.text:
My sweet tooth, and it's
really driving me nuts.

1841.77.text:
You ought to
see a dentist.

1844.34.text:
But he might
want to pull it,

1847.28.text:
and I don't like people
pulling at me.

1850.98.text:
If they want to pull
they should pull

1856.56.text:
So true, said the
little girl's father,

1860.19.text:
people should pull at
their own pullables

1863.93.text:
and let other people's
pullables alone.

1867.73.text:
But still, he asked again, I
wonder if you've seen

1872.04.text:
a little girl made of sugar and
spice and everything nice?

1890.56.text:
- "Dirge Without Music"
by Edna St. Vincent Millay.

1900.03.text:
I am not resigned to
the shutting away

1903.27.text:
of loving hearts in
the hard ground.

1906.87.text:
So it is, and so it will
be, for so it has been,

1912.38.text:
time out of mind: Into
the darkness they go,

1921.62.text:
Crowned With lilies
and with laurel they go;

1929.69.text:
Lovers and thinkers,
into the earth with you.

1933.90.text:
Be one with the dull,
the indiscriminate dust.

1939.24.text:
A fragment of what you
felt, of what you knew,

1954.25.text:
The answers quick and
keen, the honest look,

1957.46.text:
the laughter, the love,-
They are gone.

1963.53.text:
They are gone to
feed the roses.

1969.03.text:
Elegant and curled
Is the blossom.

1982.58.text:
More precious was
the light in your eyes

1986.99.text:
than all the roses
in the world.

1991.42.text:
Down, down, down into the
darkness of the grave

1997.76.text:
Gently they go, the
beautiful, the tender, the kind;

2042.34.text:
Like Crusoe with the
bootless gold we stand

2045.61.text:
Upon the desert
verge of death, and say:

2049.35.text:
"What shall avail the
woes of yesterday

2052.95.text:
To buy to-morrow's
wisdom, in the land

2055.95.text:
Whose currency
is strange unto our hand?

2060.49.text:
In life's small market
they had served to pay

2064.73.text:
Some late-found rapture,
could we but delay

2069.20.text:
Till Time hath matched our
means to our demand."

2075.34.text:
But otherwise
Fate wills it, for, behold,

2079.84.text:
Our gathered strength
of individual pain,

2083.25.text:
When Time's long
alchemy hath made it gold,

2087.05.text:
Dies with us-hoarded
all these years in vain,

2095.49.text:
Since those that might be
heir to it the mould

2099.40.text:
Renew, and coin themselves
new griefs again.

2106.57.text:
O Death, we come
full-handed to thy gate,

2111.78.text:
Rich with strange
burden of the mingled years,

2115.91.text:
Gains and renunciations,
mirth and tears,

2120.12.text:
And love's oblivion,
and remembering hate,

2124.06.text:
Nor know we what
compulsion laid such freight

2127.83.text:
Upon our souls-and
shall our hopes and fears

2141.27.text:
And sell us the one joy
for which we wait.

2147.15.text:
Had we lived longer,
like had such for sale,

2151.52.text:
With the last coin of
sorrow purchased cheap,

2156.72.text:
But now we stand
before thy shadowy pale,

2161.29.text:
And all our longings lie
within thy keep-

2168.77.text:
Death, can it be the years
shall naught avail?

2178.28.text:
"Not so," Death answered,
"they shall purchase sleep."

2208.11.text:
Don't take it
personal, they said;

2213.04.text:
but I did, I took it all quite
personal- the breeze

2220.22.text:
and the river and the
color of the fields;

2225.22.text:
the price of
grapefruit and stamps,

2229.93.text:
the wet hair of women
in the rain-

2234.83.text:
And I cursed
what hurt me

2241.41.text:
and I praised
what gave me joy,

2244.94.text:
the most simple-minded
of possible responses.

2250.45.text:
The government
reminded me of my father,

2254.05.text:
with its deafness
and its laws,

2259.59.text:
and the weather
reminded me of my mom,

2269.03.text:
Enjoy it while you can,
they said of Happiness

2275.31.text:
Think first, 
they said of Talk

2282.15.text:
Get over it, they said at the
School of Broken Hearts

2287.82.text:
but I couldn't
and I didn't

2291.16.text:
and I don't believe in
the clean break;

2295.39.text:
I believe in the
compound fracture

2299.26.text:
served with a
sauce of dirty regret,

2303.40.text:
I believe in saying it all and
taking it all back

2307.34.text:
and saying it again
for good measure

2309.51.text:
while the air fills
up with I'm-Sorries

2314.51.text:
and the trees look
seasick in the wind.

2322.12.text:
Can you blame me
for making a scene?

2330.46.text:
the moon disappearing
over a ridge of cloud.

2336.57.text:
I was the dog, chained
in some fool's backyard;

2341.61.text:
barking and barking: trying
to convince everything else

2372.97.text:
We aren't serious
when we're seventeen.

2378.21.text:
-One fine evening, to
hell with beer and lemonade,

2382.45.text:
Noisy cafés with
their shining lamps!

2386.48.text:
We walk under the green
linden trees of the park

2391.42.text:
The lindens smell good in
the good June evenings!

2397.96.text:
At times the air is so scented
that we close our eyes.

2402.17.text:
The wind laden with sounds-
the town isn't far-

2408.24.text:
Has the smell of
grapevines and beer ...

2413.31.text:
-There you can see
a very small patch

2416.78.text:
Of dark blue, framed
by a little branch,

2421.52.text:
Pinned up by a
naughty star, that melts

2424.69.text:
In gentle quivers,
small and very white...

2437.87.text: We are overcome by it all

2440.61.text:
The sap is champagne
and goes to our head...

2445.08.text:
We talked a lot and feel
a kiss on our lips

2451.38.text:
Trembling there like
a small insect...

2455.19.text:
Our wild heart moves through
novels like Robinson Crusoe,

2458.86.text:
-When, in the light
of a pale street lamp,

2462.93.text:
A girl goes by attractive
and charming

2471.80.text:
Under the shadow of her
father's terrible collar ...

2477.44.text:
And as she finds
you incredibly naïve,

2483.45.text:
She turns abruptly
and in a lively way ...

2499.06.text:
Occupied until the
month of August.

2509.41.text:
All your friends go off,
you are ridiculous.

2517.28.text:
Then one evening
the girl you worship

2529.79.text:
you return to
the bright cafés,

2534.53.text:
You ask for beer
or lemonade ...

2540.04.text:
We're not serious when
we are seventeen

2546.18.text:
And when we have green
linden trees in the park.

2574.87.text:
What torture lurks within
a single thought

2580.24.text:
When grown too constant;
and however kind,

2587.08.text:
However welcome still,
the weary mind

2603.87.text:
The old delight is
with us but to find

2607.87.text:
That all recurring
joy is pain refined,

2613.54.text:
Become a habit, and
we struggle, caught.

2621.62.text:
You lie upon my
heart as on a nest,

2627.43.text:
Folded in peace, for
you can never know

2632.43.text:
How crushed I am
with having you at rest

2647.11.text:
You bind my freedom
from its rightful quest.

2654.65.text:
In mercy lift your
drooping wings and go.

2683.58.text:
We have all seen
them circling pastures,

2688.02.text:
have looked up from
the mouth of a barn,

2691.66.text:
a pine clearing, the fences
of our own backyards,

2697.60.text:
and have stood amazed by
the one slow wing beat,

2708.04.text:
But I had never
seen so many so close,

2712.21.text:
hundreds, every limb of the
dead oak feathered black,

2718.62.text:
and I cut the engine, let the
river grab the john boat

2723.02.text: and pull it toward the tree.

2725.82.text:
The black leaves shined,
the pink fruit blossomed red,

2737.23.text:
Then, as I passed
under their dream,

2741.07.text:
I saw for the first
time its soft countenance,

2748.88.text:
the raw fleshy jowls
wrinkled and generous,

2753.88.text:
like the faces of
the very old

2756.69.text:
who have grown to
empathize with everything.

2760.49.text:
And I drifted away
from them, slow,

2764.36.text:
on the pull of the
river, reluctant,

2768.40.text:
looking back at their roost,
calling them what I'd never

2783.31.text:
who flock to the
side of the poisoned fox,

2786.72.text:
the mud turtle crushed on
the shoulder of the road,

2791.19.text:
who pray over the leaf-graves
of the anonymous lost,

2796.23.text:
with mercy enough to consume
us all and give us wings.

2811.94.text:
- Kevin Farrell: Welcome back
for the final round of the

2813.78.text:
Poetry Out Loud 2016
Mississippi Recitation Contest.

2817.18.text:
The scores from the first
and second rounds have been

2818.88.text:
tabulated and the three
highest-scoring contestants

2821.29.text:
will now each
recite a third poem.

2823.99.text:
The scores they earn in this
round will be added to their

2825.92.text:
standing scores and will be
used to select Mississippi's

2828.63.text:
representative to the Poetry
Out Loud National Recitation

2831.46.text:
Contest to be
held in Washington, D.C.,

2836.67.text:
The contestants in
alphabetical order are

2839.30.text:
Emma Goussett, Brittanie
Harrow, and Lawson Marchetti.

2853.05.text:
Now we begin the third and final
round of the Poetry Out Loud

2858.32.text:
First up is Emma Gousset, a
Junior at Tupelo High School.

2871.57.text:
- "The Maid's Lament"
by Walter Savage Landor.

2881.01.text:
and yet, now he
is gone,

2887.85.text:
I check'd him
while he spoke;

2895.79.text:
For reasons not to
love him once I sought,

2906.40.text:
I now would give
My love could he but live

2910.01.text:
Who lately lived
for me, and, when he found

2916.75.text:
He hid his face amid
the shades of death.

2922.39.text:
I waste for him my breath
Who wasted his for me!

2927.76.text:
but mine returns, And this
lorn bosom burns

2933.60.text:
With stifling heat,
heaving it up in sleep,

2940.34.text:
Tears that had
melted his soft heart:

2944.51.text:
for years Wept he
as bitter tears.

2948.95.text:
Merciful God! such
was his latest prayer,

2960.96.text:
Quieter is his breath,
his breast more cold,

2968.80.text:
Where children spell,
athwart the churchyard gate,

2972.87.text:
His name and
life's brief date.

2978.18.text:
Pray for him, gentle
souls, whoe'er you be,

2983.71.text:
And oh! pray too
for me!

2995.93.text:
- Next is Brittanie Harrow, a
Senior at St. Martin School.

3009.44.text:
- "Sonnets from the Portuguese
43: How do I love thee?

3013.84.text:
Let me count the ways" by
Elizabeth Barrett Browning.

3029.26.text:
I love thee to the depth
and breadth and height

3035.27.text:
My soul can reach,
when feeling out of sight

3039.44.text:
For the ends of being
and ideal grace.

3045.38.text:
I love thee to the level
of every day's

3050.25.text:
Most quiet need, by sun
and candle-light.

3058.62.text:
I love thee freely, as
men strive for right;

3062.79.text:
I love thee purely, as
they turn from praise.

3068.70.text:
I love thee with the
passion put to use

3071.80.text:
In my old griefs, and with
my childhood's faith.

3077.98.text:
I love thee with a love
I seemed to lose

3085.58.text:
I love thee with
the breath,

3090.49.text:
Smiles, tears, of all my
life; and, if God choose,

3099.46.text:
I shall but love thee
better after death.

3114.78.text:
- Our final recitation
is by Lawson Marchetti,

3117.45.text:
a Junior at Jackson
Preparatory School.

3147.04.text:
and I wrote
the words "king salmon"

3149.48.text:
on a piece of paper
and mailed it to you.

3154.18.text:
When you opened it would you
remember that afternoon we

3156.72.text:
spent together in the yellow
boat when the early whales

3161.89.text:
were feeding and we caught
our first fish of the year?

3169.33.text:
Or would you remember
that time off Cape Flattery

3173.00.text:
when you were a little
girl: your father smoking,

3177.91.text:
telling stories as
he ran the boat,

3181.31.text:
then the tug and zing of that
very first fish spooling off

3186.85.text:
into the gray-green world;
you laughing and brushing back

3192.49.text:
your hair before
setting the hook?

3197.19.text:
I know I am hard to understand
sometimes particularly when

3200.30.text:
you are standing
at the post office

3202.50.text:
with only a piece of paper
saying "king salmon" on it

3205.80.text:
but just think of
it as a promissory note

3213.54.text:
that thrill pulling your
mind into deep water

3216.51.text:
is how I feel about you
every, single day.

3232.23.text:
- And now, the announcement
you've all been waiting to

3233.73.text:
hear - the naming of our third
and second place finalists,

3239.30.text:
With me on stage to
present this year's awards

3241.17.text:
is Malcolm White,
the Executive Director

3250.85.text:
The 2016 Mississippi Poetry
Out Loud third-place finalist

3264.39.text:
The 2016 Mississippi Poetry
Out Loud second-place finalist

3268.20.text:
and recipient of a $100 award
and a $200 stipend

3271.80.text:
for her school library
is Emma Gousset.

3285.38.text:
So that means that the 2016
Mississippi Poetry Out Loud

3288.12.text:
state champion and
recipient of a $200 award,

3291.36.text:
and an all-expense-paid trip
for two to Washington, D.C.,

3294.39.text:
and a $500 stipend
for his school library

3313.14.text:
- Charlotte Smelser:
Thank you, Kevin Farrell,

3314.88.text:
and thanks to Kyle Baughman
and Ben Steadman,

3323.35.text:
Congratulations and thanks
to everyone who contributed

3326.49.text:
to the success of Poetry
Out Loud: the teachers,

3332.66.text:
volunteers, and
judges, and to the schools,

3334.73.text:
businesses and organizations
who partnered with the

3337.47.text:
Mississippi Arts Commission
to bring this great program

3340.70.text:
to the students of
our state, including:

3343.44.text:
The Yoknapatawpha Arts
Council in Oxford.

3345.98.text:
The Margaret Walker Alexander
National Research Center

3350.85.text:
The Lauren Rogers
Museum of Art in Laurel.

3353.58.text:
The Lafayette County &
Oxford Public Library.

3356.75.text:
Parkway Heights United
Methodist Church in Hattiesburg.

3360.22.text:
The Mary C. O'Keefe Cultural
Center of Arts and Education

3364.93.text:
And, of course, Mississippi
Public Broadcasting.

3368.47.text:
Registration for 2017 Poetry
Out Loud Mississippi Contest

3377.11.text:
Any and all schools that
teach students in grades nine

3379.41.text:
through twelve are encouraged
to go to the Mississippi Arts

3382.45.text:
Commission's website at
www.arts.ms.gov to find more

3394.36.text:
We hope you'll join
us again next year!
